titleStmt.title: Disturbances in iron homeostasis result in accelerated rejection after experimental heart transplantation

affiliation.orgName: Department of Visceral, Abdominal and Transplantation Surgery
Department of Visceral, Abdominal and Transplantation Surgery
Department of Visceral, Abdominal and Transplantation Surgery
Department of Visceral, Abdominal and Transplantation Surgery

analytic.title: Disturbances in iron homeostasis result in accelerated rejection after experimental heart transplantation

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: BACKGROUND: Clinical data suggest that iron disturbances deleteriously affect graft survival after heart transplantation (HTx), but immunological mechanisms underlying this phenomenon have not yet been elucidated.

METHODS: To identify the mechanistic influence of iron in a murine model of HTx, fully allogeneic BALB/c donor organs were transplanted into iron-overloaded or iron-deficient C57BL/6 mice, and recipients were analyzed for functional and immunological parameters.

RESULTS: After HTx, iron overload accelerated acute rejection as observed by shortened graft survival (HTx vs HTx þ iron; p ¼ 0.01), elevated rejection score (p o 0.01), and induction of troponin T (p o 0.01).

Compared with controls, allografts and recipient spleens derived from iron-overloaded recipients were characterized by a pronounced graft infiltration of CD4 þ T cells (p o 0.01), CD3 À NKp46 þ natural killer cells (p o 0.05), and reduced frequencies of regulatory T cells (p o 0.01).
This was accompanied by lower mRNA expression levels of anti-inflammatory cytokines, including interleukin-10, transforming graft factor-β, and Foxp3.

Cardiac allograft survival was further tested under co-stimulation blockade (CTLA4-Ig) showing that naïve grafts transplanted into iron-overloaded recipients illustrated restricted graft outcome compared with wild types (p ¼ 0.0051), which was rescued after treatment with the iron chelator deferoxamine.

Iron deficiency (ID) also resulted in enhanced intragraft infiltration of inflammatory cells and accelerated rejection in the acute setting (HTx vs HTx þ ID; p ¼ 0.02) and after co-stimulation blockade (p ¼ 0.0059).

CONCLUSIONS: We provide novel insights into the understanding of disturbances in iron homeostasis and their consequences after HTX, allowing novel insights regarding improvements in personalized immunosuppression to prolong allograft survival.
medication remains an important limitation for long-term graft survival. 1
The development of treatment schemes in terms of personalized immunosuppression could provide a future approach to overcoming these limitations.

The basic prerequisite for personalized medication comprises a detailed pre-transplant risk evaluation based on molecular and immunological parameters in the recipient a priori. 2 Recently, in the search for novel bioparameters indicative for tolerance, alterations in iron metabolism were suggested to predict intragraft alloimmune responses. 3
ecause iron status is not routinely assessed in SOT allograft recipients, the exact impact of iron disturbances in these patients remains unknown. 4
However, accumulating studies have already shown that iron overload is present in a substantial proportion of SOT recipients.

This is due to the fact that iron overload can result from hereditary diseases, such as hemochromatosis or β-thalassemia (primary iron overload), 5,6 and secondarily, such as from blood transfusions. 7,8
Each unit of transfused blood contains 220-250 mg of iron, an amount that by far exceeds the daily intestinal absorption of 1-2 mg of nutritional iron required for iron homeostasis. 9,10
Taking into account the body's inability to excrete excess iron, it becomes evident that chronic transfusions lead to progressive and pathologic iron accumulation.
Accordingly, elevated iron levels are prevalent in patients with end-stage renal disease and patients with iron overload cardiomyopathy. 8
Iron deficiency (ID) is also a prevalent finding in SOT recipients. 11
3][14] This is of particular note, as several clinical observations indicate detrimental outcomes of SOT in recipients with iron overload and ID.

Several clinical studies have highlighted inferior outcomes after kidney transplantation in patients with increased iron levels, 7,15,16 and oral iron supplementation might be associated with higher rates of graft rejection. 17

Likewise, after liver transplantation, primary and secondary iron overload deleteriously affects both graft and patient survival rates, 18 and elevated iron levels have been suggested as an independent risk factor for mortality after transplantation. 19
urthermore, iron accumulation in lung allografts was shown to be associated with acute rejection. 20
To date, only 1 report exists regarding HTx in patients with iron overload cardiomyopathy, indicating inferior survival rates in the long-term. 21
ron seems to exert a considerable influence on immune cell functions in vitro.
The influence of iron overload has been best documented for monocytes 22 but also applies to other immune cells, including CD8 þ T cells, 23 natural killer (NK) cells, 24 and CD4 þ T cells. 25
Although less well understood, ID also impairs functions of innate and adaptive cell subtypes, such as the translocation capacity and blastogenesis of T lymphocytes. 26
Increasing evidence substantiates that iron overload and ID are frequent in SOT recipients and furthermore associated with inferior post-transplantation outcomes.
However, the immanent precondition is the detailed understanding of the mechanisms underlying the clinically made observations.
Male C57BL/6 (H-2 b ) and BALB/c (H-2 d ) mice (12 weeks old) weighing 20-25 g were obtained from Charles River Laboratories (Sulzfeld, Germany).

Animals were housed under standard conditions and received humane care in compliance with the "Principles of Laboratory Animal Care" (National Institutes of Health Publication No. 86 -23, revised 1985).
Animal experiments were performed in accordance with the guidelines of the Medical University of Innsbruck and the Austrian Ministry for Science and Education, Vienna (66.011/0078-II/3b/2012).

Recipient mice were dichotomized, receiving standard diet either enriched with iron (25 g iron/kg; Altromin Spezialfutter GmbH, Lage, Germany) or deficient for iron (o10 mg/kg), whereas control mice received standard diet without iron supplementation for 4 weeks.
Fully allogeneic BALB/cÀ (donor) derived hearts were transplanted into C57BL/6 recipients using a heterotopic HTx model recently described by us 27,28 and others. 29

For long-term cardiac allograft survival experiments, a single injection of Abatacept (10 mg/kg; Bristol-Myers Squibb, Munich, Germany) was administered via intraperitoneal injection 48 hours after HTx in recipients with or without prior iron overload.

To assess whether iron chelation can affect long-term outcomes in iron-overloaded recipients, daily intraperitoneal injections of deferoxamine mesylate (100 mg/kg; Desferal; Novartis, Basel, Switzerland) were performed for 2 weeks after HTx.

For the generation of single cell suspensions from murine hearts, whole organs were mechanically shredded and then digested with collagenase II (Invitrogen Corp., Carlsbad, CA) plus DNase (Invitrogen Corp.) in 10 ml of medium for 45 minutes at 371C.
Mononuclear cells from spleens were isolated by Histopaque-1083 (Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO) density gradient centrifugation.
For flow cytometry, 1 Â 10 6 cells were incubated for 15 minutes at 41C with combinations of the antibodies listed in Table S1 (available in the online version of this article at www.jhltonline.
org).
Data were analyzed using FlowJo software 9.3 (Tree Star Inc., Ashland, OR).
Structural changes in hearts were evaluated at the end of the respective observation period by the same pathologist (G.S.), who was blinded to all experimental data.
Specimens were fixed in 4% buffered formalin, paraffin-embedded, stained with hematoxylineosin, and assessed by light microscopy.
Graft rejection was scored according to the standards of the International Society of Heart and Lung Transplantation (ISHLT).
Serum samples were stored in aliquots at À801C until laboratory measurements were performed.
High-sensitivity cardiac troponin T was measured using a commercially available assay (hs-cTnT recalibrated assay, 5th generation) on an E170 instrument
Iron deposit in tissue sections was detected by Perl's Prussian blue staining.

Quantification of iron deposit was performed using Scheuer's scoring system, modified according to Searle et al. 30 Plasma iron concentration was quantified using a commercial kit (QuantiChrom Iron Assay Kit; BioAssay Systems, Hayward, CA), under strict compliance with the manufacturer's instructions.

div.head: Real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction

p.s: Real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction was performed as recently described. 28
In brief, total RNA from snapfrozen organs (spleen, heart) was extracted using the NucleoSpin RNA Kit (Macherey-Nagel GmbH & Co., Düren, Germany) according to the manufacturer's instructions.
Integrity of RNA was Iron overload results in increased splenic frequencies of CD4 þ T cells and NK cells.
Analysis of lymphocyte subsets isolated from solid organs revealed significantly increased frequencies of CD3 þ CD4 þ T and CD3 À NKp46 þ cells in spleens derived from mice with iron overload.
No significant changes were observed for CD3 þ CD8 þ T cells, MHCII þ CD11c high DCs, or T reg cells.
Data are presented as median Ϯ range.
Statistically significant differences between naïve and naïveþFe animals were tested with Mann-Whitney U test.
*p o 0.05, n ¼ 5-8 animals/group.
checked using a NanoDrop 2000 spectrophotometer.
Real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction for gene expression analysis was performed with the ABI PRISM 7500 Sequence Detection System (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA).
Specific gene expression was normalized to the housekeeping gene hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HPRT) using the formula 2 ÀΔCt .
Results are expressed as median Ϯ range.
Statistical analysis was performed using GraphPad Prism 5 (GraphPad Software, Inc., La Jolla, CA).
Statistical significance between 2 groups was determined using the Mann-Whitney U test for non-parametric analyses.
A p-value of o 0.05 was considered statistically significant (n.s., not significant).
Kaplan-Meier plots were used to analyze graft survival, and a log-rank test was employed to assess the statistical significance of differences between survival curves.

div.head: Oral iron supplementation leads to iron overload in solid organs

p.s: Following oral iron supplementation for 4 weeks, C57BL/6 mice displayed marked iron deposits in liver, kidney, heart, and spleen (Figure 1A).
Histologic grading revealed the largest amounts of iron in the liver (p o 0.05) and spleen (o 0.05), whereas minor deposits were found in kidney (p o 0.05) and heart (p ¼ n.s.) (Figure 1B).
In line with increased tissue iron stores, serum iron levels were significantly elevated in mice with iron overload (p o 0.05) (Figure 1C).
These data show that nutritional iron supplementation for 4 weeks results in a highly reproducible model of iron overload within the range of clinical relevance.

div.head: Iron overload alters immune cell frequencies in the recipient before transplantation

p.s: We addressed whether iron overload affects the recipient's immune compartments per se before transplantation.
As shown in Figure 2, iron overload results in an altered composition of immune subsets in solid organs.
Concerning CD3 þ CD4 þ T cells, a discrete increase was observed in the heart (p ¼ 0.07; n.s.) and spleen (p ¼ 0.1; n.s.), whereas no changes were observed for CD3 þ CD8 þ T cells.

In addition, induced frequencies of CD3 À NKp46 þ NK cells were detected in the spleen (p o 0.05), whereas MHCII þ CD11c highþ dendritic cells (DCs) or regulatory T cells (T reg ) remained unaffected (Figure 2).

To evaluate whether organ-specific alterations in the composition of immune subsets were associated with an altered inflammatory milieu, gene expression analysis was performed in spleens and hearts of naïve animals, with or without prior iron overload.

Although no significant changes could be detected for the heart, a decrease in the candidate genes Foxp3 (p o 0.05) and interleukin-10 (p ¼ 0.07) and an increase of perforin (p ¼ 0.06) were observed solely in spleens (Figure S1 [available in the online version of this article at www.jhltonline.org]).

div.head: Iron overload results in decreased graft survival after HTx

p.s: Next, we examined the potential consequences of iron overload on allograft survival.
For this reason, BALB/c donor hearts were transplanted into C57BL/6 recipients without (HTx) or with prior iron overload (HTxþFe).
Grafts transplanted into recipients with iron supplementation showed a significantly poorer median graft survival (HTxþFe 7.5 days vs HTx 9 days; p ¼ 0.0179) (Figure 3A).

Grafts derived from recipients with iron overload were characterized by a significantly higher frequency of graft-infiltrating cells (Figure 3B), reflected by a significantly higher median ISHLT rejection score in mice with iron overload compared with control mice (p o 0.01) (Figure 3C).
In accordance with the histological findings, cardiac troponin T levels, an index of cardiac cell damage, were significantly higher in iron-overloaded recipients (p o 0.001) (Figure 3D).
Iron overload alone did not alter troponin T levels in naïve animals (p ¼ n.s.), excluding a potential bias through direct iron-mediated cardiotoxic influences.

div.head: Induced frequencies of CD4 þ T cells and NK cells after HTx in iron-overloaded recipients

p.s: Given that iron overload deteriorates graft function via accelerated graft rejection, we aimed to characterize the underlying immunological mechanisms of graft rejection at day 5 post-transplantation.
Although numbers of intragraft cytotoxic CD8 þ T cells were equally high in both experimental groups, a pronounced graft infiltration of CD4 þ T lymphocytes was observed (p o 0.01) (Figure 4).

CD3 À NKp46 þ NK cells were also significantly induced in the graft (p o 0.05) and spleen (p o 0.001), whereas significantly higher levels of MHCII þ CD11c high DCs were observed in spleen only (p o 0.001).
This observation was accompanied by significantly lower levels of T reg in both allograft (po0.001) and recipient (po0.001)
spleen (Figure 4).

The latter observation was further supported by a clear downregulation of Foxp3, transforming growth factor-β, and interleukin-10 messenger RNA expression in graft and spleen, whereas inflammatory cytokines including interleukin-6 and tumor necrosis factor-α were significantly induced in heart allografts only (p o 0.05) (Figure S2 [available in the online version of this article at www. jhltonline.org]).

div.head: Iron chelation leads to prolonged graft survival

p.s: Next, we aimed to assess graft survival rates in a long-term transplantation setting.
For this purpose, C57BL/6 recipient mice received a single dose of the co-stimulatory agent CTLA4-Ig (Abatacept).
Median graft survival in this model was 50 days (HTx), whereas recipients with iron supplementation (HTxþFe) displayed a significantly reduced median graft survival of 28 days (p ¼ 0.0051).

Treatment of iron-overloaded mice with deferoxamine (HTxþFeþ DEF) resulted in a median graft survival comparable to non-iron-supplemented recipients (HTxþFeþDEF 53 days vs HTx 50 days; p ¼ 0.9) (Figure 5).

div.head: Increased frequencies of inflammatory cells in naïve hearts derived from iron-deficient mice

p.s: To assess whether the observed immunological changes underlying an iron overload also apply to an ID status, we characterized the effects of ID in naïve animals.
Low-iron diet resulted in decreased serum iron levels in mice (Figure 3 [available in the online version of this article at www.jhltonline.org])
and caused a significant cardiac increase of CD4 þ T cells, CD8 þ T cells, NK cells, and MHCII þ CD11c high cells (p o 0.01).
In contrast to the iron overload status, no significant changes were observed for splenic or cardiac T reg frequencies (Figure 6).

div.head: Iron deficiency results in decreased graft survival after HTx

p.s: We transplanted BALB/c donor hearts into C57BL/6 recipients without (HTx) or with ID (HTxþID).

Comparable to iron overload, ID in the recipient results in accelerated rejection in the acute model illustrating a poorer median graft survival (HTxþID 7 days vs HTx 9 days; p ¼ 0.02) (Figure 7A) reflected by a significantly higher median ISHLT rejection score in mice with ID compared with control mice (p o 0.05) (Figure 7B).
Although we did not detect differences for cardiac troponin T levels (Figure 7C), histology illustrated significantly higher infiltration of inflammatory cells (Figure 7D).
This was further reflected Iron overload leads to impaired long-term survival.
Co-stimulation blockade was applied to achieve long-term survival in the acute heart allograft model (HTx) resulting in a median survival of 50 days.

Contrarily, recipients with iron supplementation displayed a significantly reduced median graft survival of 28 days, whereas iron chelation therapy of iron-supplemented mice with deferoxamine (HTXþAbaþDEF) resulted in a median graft survival comparable to recipients without iron supplementation (HTXþAba, 53 days).
HTX, heart transplantation; Aba, Abatacept; DEF, deferoxamine.

by significantly higher numbers of T cells, NK cells, and DCs in the cardiac graft (p o 0.01) and by significantly higher frequencies of NK cells (p o 0.05) and DCs (p o 0.01) in the recipient spleen, whereas no changes were observed for T reg (Figure 8) and Foxp3 expression (Figure S4 [available in the online version of this article at www. jhltonline.org]).
Finally, we assessed graft survival rates in the long-term transplantation setting applying co-stimulation blockade.

According to the iron-overloaded group, ID recipients (HTxþID) displayed a significantly reduced median graft survival of 24 days vs median survival of 50 days of the control group (p ¼ 0.0059) (Figure S5 Figure 6 ID alters the immune composition in naïve animals.
ID resulted in significantly increased frequencies of [available in the online version of this article at www. jhltonline.org]).

div.formula: CD3 þ CD4 þ T cells, CD3 þ CD8 þ T cells, CD3 À NKp46 þ NK

p.s: Maintenance of an exact balance of the body's iron stores is a complex and vital condition.
Since the discovery of hepcidin, the master iron regulatory hormone, knowledge of the body's iron homeostasis has continuously grown. 31

wing to the dependence of microorganisms on iron as an essential cofactor for proliferation, iron redistribution via the hepcidin-ferroportin axis has been recognized as an evolutionarily developed anti-microbial strategy in mammals. 32
Dysregulation of iron homeostasis deleteriously affects multiple organ systems, implying not yet entirely understood consequences for immune compartments. 33
r data reveal that disturbances of iron homeostasis per se result in an altered composition of immune subsets in various solid organs.

CD8 þ and CD4 þ T cell frequencies were slightly increased in the heart and spleen in recipients with iron overload (Figure 2), whereas ID triggered a significant influx of innate immune subsets (NK cells and DCs) as well as CD4 þ and CD8 þ T cells into naïve hearts (Figure 6).

These observations are likely to apply also in humans, as abnormally high CD4:CD8 ratios of peripheral T lymphocytes have been reported in patients with hereditary hemochromatosis, 22,34 although, to our knowledge, no analysis of tissue-resident lymphocytes has so far been conducted.
However, in rodent models of experimental iron overload generated with targeted heme oxygenase 1 (Hmox1) mutations, high CD4:CD8 ratios and large numbers of activated CD4 þ T cells were observed. 35
oncerning innate subsets, Flynn et al 36 suggested a link between iron storage levels and circulating NK cells.
Likewise, we observed induced frequencies of systemic NK cells after both experimental iron overload and deficiency in naïve animals (Figures 2 and 6).

Graft failure occurred significantly earlier in HTx recipients with iron overload than in control mice (Figures 3A and 5), underlining that the reported clinical observations can be reproduced under experimental conditions.
Furthermore, restoration of iron homeostasis in ironsupplemented mice with deferoxamine (HTxþDEF) resulted in a comparable median graft survival to non-ironsupplemented recipients (Figure 5).

However, rejection was characterized by enhanced CD4 þ T cell and NK cell frequencies in recipients with iron overload, and this effect was accompanied by elevated pro-inflammatory marker expression in the graft and spleen, whereas the expression of anti-inflammatory cytokines was significantly diminished in both organs.

Tumor necrosis factor-α release by CD4 þ T cells has been shown to be crucially involved in kidney allograft rejection, 37,38 and blockade of tumor necrosis factor-α prolongs allograft survival in rodent models. 39

div.head: Figure 8

p.s: Accelerated rejection due to iron deficiency is associated with induced frequencies of CD4 þ T cells, CD8 þ T cells, NK cells, and DCs.

Compared with control mice, significantly higher frequencies of As T reg cells are known to exert inflammatory suppressor functions via the release of IL-10 or transforming growth factor-β, 40 we found that T reg cells were significantly reduced in both the graft and the spleen, in keeping with a decrease in Foxp3 mRNA expression (Figure S2 [available in the online version of this article at www.jhltonline.org]).

div.formula: CD3 þ CD4 þ T cells, CD3 À NKp46 þ NK cells

p.s: ID in the HTx recipient also resulted in enhanced intragraft infiltration of inflammatory cells (Figure 8) and accelerated rejection in the acute setting and after costimulation blockade (Figure 7 and Figure S5 [available in the online version of this article at www.jhltonline.org]).
Clinically, ID is frequent in patients with heart failure with or without anemia and represents an independent predictor of death or urgent HTx. 4,41
Furthermore, inadequate iron stores at the time of transplantation have been ruled out as a major contributor to post-transplant anemia (PTA). 12
In kidney transplant recipients, PTA incidence has been reported to be 470% at the time of transplantation and 20%-30% after 1 year. 42,43
Similarly high percentages have been reported among HTX 42 or liver transplant recipi ents. 44,45
Consequences of PTA are deleterious, being associated not only with impaired graft survival 46 but also with increased mortality rates. 47,48
Although iron supple mentation has been reported to be beneficial when PTA occurs after SOT, 49 insufficient data are available on iron supplementation before surgery.

In conclusion, our data illustrate the decisive role of disturbances in iron homeostasis for graft survival, indicating that treatment of iron disturbances in graft recipients improves outcomes, which may have direct implications regarding improved clinical management after SOT.
Figure 1 Oral iron supplementation leads to iron deposition in solid organs.
(A) After 4 weeks of oral iron supplementation, C57BL/6 mice (naïveþFe) showed significant iron deposits in solid organs, including liver, kidney, and spleen.
Only minimal iron staining was detected in heart tissue.
Histologic figures from n ¼ 6 animals/group are shown.
(B) Quantification of iron deposit revealed the largest iron deposit in liver and spleen.
(C) Iron overload leads to increased total serum iron content.
Data are presented as median Ϯ range of n ¼ 4-9 animals/group Ϯ SEM.
Statistically significant differences between naïve and naïveþFe animals were tested with Mann-Whitney U test.
Figure 2Iron overload results in increased splenic frequencies of CD4 þ T cells and NK cells.
Analysis of lymphocyte subsets isolated from solid organs revealed significantly increased frequencies of CD3 þ CD4 þ T and CD3 À NKp46 þ cells in spleens derived from mice with iron overload.
No significant changes were observed for CD3 þ CD8 þ T cells, MHCII þ CD11c high DCs, or T reg cells.
Data are presented as median Ϯ range.
Statistically significant differences between naïve and naïveþFe animals were tested with Mann-Whitney U test.
*p o 0.05, n ¼ 5-8 animals/group.
Figure 3Accelerated acute rejection of heart allografts by recipients with iron overload.
(A) Naïve BALB/c-derived donor hearts were rejected faster when transplanted into C57BL/6 recipients with iron overload than into naïve C57BL/6 recipients (HTxþFe 7.5 days vs HTx 9 days; p ¼ 0.0179).
(B) Histologic staining revealed clearly higher graft-infiltrating lymphocyte counts in donor hearts engrafted into recipients with iron supplementation.
Figures from n ¼4-6 experiments are shown.
(C) ISHLT rejection score and (D) troponin T as functional parameters of heart function were significantly induced.
Data are presented as median Ϯ range.
Statistically significant differences between naïve and naïveþFe recipients were tested with Mann-Whitney U test.
Figure 4Accelerated rejection due to iron overload is associated with induced frequencies of CD4 þ T and NK cells but reduced frequencies of T reg cells.

At day 5 post-transplantation, significantly induced frequencies of CD3 þ CD4 þ T and CD3 À NKp46 þ NK cells were detected in heart allografts and spleens derived from recipients with iron overload compared with control mice.

Furthermore, HTx in recipients with iron supplementation resulted in significantly reduced frequencies of MHCII þ CD11c high DCs, whereas T reg cells were significantly reduced in both allografts and spleens.
Data are presented as median Ϯ range.
Statistically significant differences between HTX and HTXþFe recipients were tested with Mann-Whitney U test.
Figure 5Iron overload leads to impaired long-term survival.
Co-stimulation blockade was applied to achieve long-term survival in the acute heart allograft model (HTx) resulting in a median survival of 50 days.

Contrarily, recipients with iron supplementation displayed a significantly reduced median graft survival of 28 days, whereas iron chelation therapy of iron-supplemented mice with deferoxamine (HTXþAbaþDEF) resulted in a median graft survival comparable to recipients without iron supplementation (HTXþAba, 53 days).
HTX, heart transplantation; Aba, Abatacept; DEF, deferoxamine.
Figure 6ID alters the immune composition in naïve animals.
ID resulted in significantly increased frequencies ofCD3 þ CD4 þ T cells, CD3 þ CD8 þ T cells, CD3 À NKp46 þ NKcells, and MHCII þ CD11c high DCs in naïve hearts.
No significant changes were observed for T reg cells.
Data are presented as median Ϯ range.
Statistically significant differences between naïve and naïveþID animals were tested with Mann-Whitney U test.
*p o 0.05, **p o 0.01, n ¼ 4-8 animals/group.

Figure 7 Accelerated rejection of heart allografts by recipients with ID. (A) Naïve BALB/c-derived donor hearts were rejected faster when transplanted into C57BL/6 recipients with ID than into naïve C57BL/6 recipients (HTxþID 7 days vs HTx 9 days; p ¼ 0.02).
(B) ISHLT rejection score was significantly higher, whereas (C) no changes were observed in troponin T. Data are presented as median Ϯ range.
(D) Histologic staining revealed clearly higher frequencies of graft-infiltrating lymphocytes in donor hearts engrafted into recipients with ID.
Figures from n ¼ 4-6 experiments are shown.
Figure 8Accelerated rejection due to iron deficiency is associated with induced frequencies of CD4 þ T cells, CD8 þ T cells, NK cells, and DCs.

Compared with control mice, significantly higher frequencies ofCD3 þ CD4 þ T cells, CD3 À NKp46 þ NK cells, and MHCII þ CD11c high DCs were detected in cardiac grafts derived from recipients with ID at day 5 post-transplantation. Simultaneously, increased frequencies of NK cells and DCs were observed in the spleen.
Contrary to the iron overload setting, no changes were detected for T reg cells.
Data are presented as median Ϯ range.
Statistically significant differences between HTX and HTXþID recipients were tested with Mann-Whitney U test.
